statement.tex:
%text Three bags contain balls as shown in the table below
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline \text{Bag} & \text{# White} & \text{# Black} & \text{# Red} \\ \hline I & 1 & 2 & 3 \\ \hline II & 2 & 1 & 1 \\ \hline III & 4 & 3 & 2 \\ \hline \end{tabular} %text
A bag is chosen at random and two balls are drawn from it. They happen to be white and red. What is the probability that they came from bag III? %

\\ %text \underline\text{What probability do we have to find} given the following events? % \begin{tabular}{|c|l|} \hline A & \text{Two balls picked - 1 red, 1 white} \\ \hline B_1 & \text{Bag 1 picked} \\ \hline B_2 & \text{Bag 2 picked} \\ \hline B_3 & \text{Bag 3 picked} \\ \hline \end{tabular}
\\ %text Given that we need to find $P(B_3\vert A)$, \underline\text{is the following correct}? %

\\ %text What would the \underline\text{values of} $P(A\vert B_1)$, $P(A\vert B_2)$ and $P(A\vert B_3)$ be?
Refer to the formula in last step. %
\\ %text Given the probabilities of drawing a red and a white ball from each bag, what then is the \underline\text{required probability - $P(B_3\vert A)$}? %

reason.tex:
%text We have already drawn a red and a white ball. But we don't know from which bag.
Not just that, the question is whether the balls came from bag III.
Hence, the required probability is \[ \qquad P\left( B_3\,\vert\, A\right) = P\left(\text{$B_3$ given A}\right) \] %

options.tex: \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline P(A\vert B_3) & P(A\vert B_2) & P(A\vert B_3) \\ \hline \frac{1}{5} & \frac{1}{3} & \frac{2}{9} \\ \hline \end{tabular}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|} \hline P(A\vert B_3) & P(A\vert B_2) & P(A\vert B_3) \\ \hline \frac{3}{8} & \frac{1}{4} & \frac{2}{7} \\ \hline \end{tabular}
